Title: I Remember
Text:
I remember when you asked me what my greatest fear was.
Harry potter on my tv.
We weren’t watching.
We never did.
I still don’t know what happens in those movies.
Sitting cross-legged,
On the floor,
In front of my couch,
Facing each other,
You asked.
I paused for a second, then I said,
“Watching myself hurt those I love most, and not being able to do anything about it.”
You sat speechless.

After a time,
I echoed the question back.
You said, “Spiders.”

I remember the first time you told me you loved me.
Arms entangled,
Legs intertwined,
Cold toes touching warm feet.
Smells of lavender and peaches.
Tastes of sweet espresso and honey.
With every kiss and touch
Our heart beats get closer to beating in unison.
You stopped me.

You stared deep into my eyes
Mine brown, like a riverbed.
Yours blue, like crystal clear water.
Hands on my cheeks,
You hold my head still.
I see worry in your eyes,
As if you are about to jump of a precipice.
Your only reassurance is that I might catch you.
Eyes bounce as you read my face,
Checking one last time for red flags.
You took a deep breath in.
A leap of faith spilled from your mouth.
“I Love You.”

“I. Love. You.”
Your heart falling,
Only hoping to be caught,
As you wait for my response.
I move your hands off my face
And put your arms around my neck.
“I love you too.”

Title: The Professor
Text:
I met you at English Dinner,
You hosted every Sunday.
At first attendance I felt like a foreigner.
Conversations consisted of Dickinson, Hamilton, and the enneagram.
All I knew was computation, calculations, and how to program.
I was a programmer and you were a poet.
Yet, you welcomed me anyway.

At a young age I learned
How to compartmentalize.
Positively reinforced by the result of a calm house.
I put my pains into their own box.
With locks, I kept them safe from those I loved.
Parents called me stoic,
Teachers said I was wise beyond my years.
Honestly, I just learned how to bight my tongue.
Was bighting so long,
When I spoke, I tasted blood.

Between bowls of vegan chili and slices of fine cheese
You taught me.
It wasn’t okay to suppress myself.
It was nonbeneficial for my mental health.
I needed to let my tongue go
And let the blood clot.
But I didn’t know how to stop biting.

You taught me the power of poetry.
A therapy I will never take for granted.
With each line that rhymed
I felt my atrophied vocal cords vibrate.
Like a guitar naturally resonates.

Truthfully, I spent most English dinners in derealization.
Another mechanism I learned to cope.
I learned how to code to hide my mental state.
But you could see through my façade.
Like Roddy Piper,
You saw me as I was.
Just a lost kid trying his best to find a home.
You could see me because you weren’t afraid to admit that you were one too.
Like we all are.
Like everyone is.

Title: Fear of Failure
Text:
A pen that has ran out of ink
Can only leave an indent on the paper,
The intent of creating without the creation.
Painting with pigment-less paint.
No matter how precise and thought out the strokes are,
The skill, the thought, the passion doesn’t show.
Singing when no one is around.
No confirmation of beauty, or anyone to listen.

I am afraid that if I don’t write something meaningful
My voice will only be heard, but not listed to.

A flashlight with a broken bulb.
It has what it needs but can’t shine.
Like a ship without a sale
My words might get lost in a stream of incoherent thought and emotions.
Like when you are trying desperately to take notes and the professor is talking too fast.
A feeble attempt to record every word of importance
Your handwriting deteriorates
To an illegible rat’s nest of cursive and print.

Being afraid of failure is just another way to feel alive.

Like riding a rollercoaster to feel scared.
Like standing over a cliff just to feel carnal urge to jump,
And say “no” to it.
So you can say you’re in control.
Because truth is, we are never in control.

Title: Starving Artist
Text:
A jobless vagabond,
Counting my days to destitution.
Maybe being a starving artist will be my restitution.
I’ll pinch pennies to buy white rice and black beans.
Maybe treat myself to some top ramen with a dash of Frank’s Red Hot.
Like a jazz musician,
I’ll improvise lines at an open mic to pick up a few dollars.
Maybe I’ll reharmonize
A melancholy cover of Sweater Weather
And impress some white collars.
People seem to like that song.
